threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

I'm in the middle of book 66 of Dio at the moment, has anyone else here read him? What are your thoughts?
I found the early books incredibly boring, as Livy had told much of the same stories, and much better.

I even liked his coverage of of the civil wars (from Sulla to Augustus), and of Caesar, though he is inferior here of course to Appian.

It may be evident my post really is more concerned with the literary aspect and the quirks and biases of the text and it's author. However, I'm posting it here rather than /lit/ as it concerns historic works.

>>14238401
The KMT started off as a broadly big tent party led by Sun Yet-Sun with a handful of principles (Three Principles of the People). Broadly speaking, some ideas are nationalism, unity of the peoples of China, some democracy/republicanism values, overthrow the monarchy, modernization, and a government that helps the people instead of oppressing them.

Note that the party itself isn't really too concerned with the method (socialism, communism, capitalism, whatever). The primary goal was establishing a modernized, democratic/republic China. The socialists and Communist Party in particular weren't opposed to the idea of a modernized, democratic/republic China and acted as the left wing of the party - opposite to militarized right-wing/fascist elements of the Party like Chiang Kai-Shek were more pro-Germany, pro-Japan whereas the left wing were more pro-USSR. The right-wing represented more business interests while the left/socialist wing represented the "workers".

This left-right wing unity fell apart after Sun Yet-sun died and Chiang began his purge of the left-wing KMT elements. After that, the KMT was associated with dictatorship, military-first, and ring-wing ideology.

>One of the ancient records handed down refers to this time of Hercules: “At the time of Kronos the Idaean Dacnyk lived around Mt Ida in Crete. One of the Dactyls was named Herakles and be may have been referred to on the Phaistos Disc which was found at Phaistos in Crete near Mt Ida and dates to about 1700 BC. According to the decipherment and translation by J. Faucounau's the Phaistos Disc refers to the funeral of a Greek king called Arion and was written in proto-lonic dialect. The name Arion is Árik in Hebrew which is the same as the name Arioch in the Old Testament, which in Elamite was written Eri-Aku giving the name Her-ak-les. The Greeks used the same rites as those of the Phoenician God Melcathrus in their worsbip of Herakles so both names are related to ach other. Herakles is probably a corruption of Melcathrus in the following manner, Mel-ca-thrus to Her-ak-les rbere the letters L and R are interchangeable as in Linear B. Mel-ca-thr could be a corruption of “Melech Terra” meaning “king of the land” and “Melech" is probably also the original source of the Elamite name Eriaku.” Eriaku might also refer to the Epic of Gilgameshs Enkidu. This record does not serve as proof but does serve to offer support for the Epic of Gilgamesh and his story

>Niō (仁王) are two wrathful and muscular guardians of the Buddha standing today at the entrance of many Buddhist temples in East Asian Buddhism in the form of frightening wrestler-like statues. last_replies.com:
It really depends on how you define oldest country. Does it have to be a single unconquered political entity with no revolutions or civil wars, even if they just resulted in a change of government but the country's borders and the people within it didn't actually change?

Just as an example, how old is France? Was it founded in
>496 when Clovis I was founded the first King of the Franks
>843 when West Francia was partitioned
>987 with the start of the Capetian dynasty
>1204 the first time a ruler was called King of France
>1453 with the end of the hundred years war
>1791 when France became a republic
>1945 when France was liberated from the Nazis (although the 4th republic would not be formed until 1946)
or
>1958 when the 5th (and current) republic was formed

or should it be something else entirely? Frankly, any of these are valid.
